data: Giacomo Manganaro, «Nuove ricerche di epigrafia siceliota», Siculorum Gymnasium 16 (1963): 51–64
The Technitai of Dionysos honour Skymnos

Neat and regular letters of the later Hellenistic period, in some cases with pronounced serifs. Omicron is full-size; omega is closed; epsilon has shorter middle bar; mu has splayed outer hastae; kappa on occasion has short arms; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; pi has equal vertical strokes and the horizontal overhangs on both sides.
Photo J. Prag, Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

The Technitai of Dionysos honour Apollodotos son of Leukios

The letters are notably less regular than . Omicron is full; omega is closed; mu has splayed hastae and extended upper strokes; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; psi has short upward angled arms; epsilon has nearly equal length bars

Very regular neat v-cut letters. The text is centred on the stone. Note the use of horizontal lines/dashes between the name and patronym of the officials. Sigma is four bar and open; Pi has short second vertical; omicron and omega are small, the latter closed.
Probably Hieronian in date, given the letter forms and the content.
Photo J. Prag, 02.03.2023, with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

Note presence of rhomboid omega and omicron, regular epsilon and sigma according to the transcription in the BM catalogue

Lettering of this sort can be observed already in the later Hellenistic period in Sicily, but the use of marble may suggest that the piece belongs in the Roman period, although the absence of Roman names in turn might suggest an earlier date. Perhaps second century CE?
Marshall, 1874-1916, The collection of ancient Greek inscriptions in the British Museum

1Νεωτέρας κατὰ βάτρια (vac.3) Ἀρχύται
2Ν̣στιοδώρου Σάνγρα τὸν ναὸν καὶ τὸ
3ἄγαλμα ἐπόησε
4ἐκ τῶν ἰδίων

l.3 reg., orig. ἐπόησε
Inscription recording the neaniskoi of the gymnasium

The text fills the face available below the cornice (and seems likely to have continued below), with probably a consistent left margin, but a less regular right margin, and some cramping in order to fit words/phrases to the line (as e.g. in line 1).

The letters are mostly regular with a fairly square module and terminal points to the strokes rather than serifs. Alpha has broken cross-bar; epsilon has nearly equal bars; zeta in the form of an I with broad crossbars; kappa has short arms; mu has sloping outer strokes and half-height mid-strokes; omicron is nearly full-size, and consistently has a central dot (in lines 2 and 3 appears to have a line underneath); rho has rounded closed eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes, and the mid-strokes extend almost the full width; phi is standard height, elliptical; omega is consistently a closed circle (without the central dot of omicron), sometimes on the baseline, sometimes traversed by the line.
Photo J. Prag, 29.06.2016, with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Cordiano, 1997, La ginnasiarchia nelle "poleis" dell'occidente mediterraneo antico

Text has sections marked out by the positioning of the first line of each section to the left, but nonetheless maintains an irregular left margin. Slight gap between the two sections of text.

Letters have pronounced terminal serifs. Alpha with straight bar; epsilon with shorter middle bar; mu with vertical first and last, shorter mid-strokes; xsi in form of Z with crossbar; omega distinctive as small circle joined to horizontal foot by a small vertical connector;
late 2nd century BCE or 1st century BCE

1Γυμνασιάρχης
2Εὐβουλίδας
3Ἡρακλείου
A gymnasiarch crowns a group of youths

15 neatly carved lines of Greek letters, of which the first four are larger. There appears to be a slight vacat at the top; lines 1-3 are indented by the equivalent of 1-2 characters at most; from line 4 onwards the left indentation increases, with clear vacats after lines 5 and 6, and a fixed left margin (c.7 cm vacat) from line 7 onwards; a vacat is consistently inserted between each name in the list from line 7 onwards.

Elegant letters with minimal serifs/terminations visible on longer strokes (e.g. on tau, sigma and epsilon). Alpha has straight bar; beta has smaller upper loop, with the two loops connected without meeting the vertical; epsilon has shorter middle bar; theta is a full-size circle with a detached horizontal stroke at the centre; kappa has full length arms; mu has near vertical first and last strokes, with the middle strokes meeting a small way above the baseline; xsi is formed of vertical with three horizontals, the middle one of shorter length; omicron is full-size; pi has equal length vertical strokes; sigma has horizontal topo and bottom strokes; phi is ovoid, with vertical taller than other letters (14-15mm); omega full size, near circular, but open at the base. Traces of a secondary text include lunate epsilon (see commentary).
Museo di Archeologia dell'Universita di Catania
Photo J. Prag 2016-05-12, by permission of Museo di Archeologia dell'Universita di Catania
a gymnasiarch crowns a group of youths

Large letters centrally placed on the stone in a single line. The text is incomplete at start and finish.

Regularly spaced letters of even height, neatly cut (a broad v-cut) with minimal terminations to the strokes. Alpha has straight bar; Kappa has short arms, centrally placed; Omicron is very small (105 mm) and midline; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes.
